newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian Oil corp set for well-oiled growth.
newsitem.headline: Indian Oil corp set for well-oiled growth.

text.p: India's biggest refiner, Indian Oil Corporation Ltd (IOC) is poised for smooth growth in coming years, analysts said on Saturday.

"According to our forecast, Indian Oil's profits should rise by 16 percent in the year to March 1998 and 26 percent in the year to March 1999," said P. Dhileepan, an analyst with Natwest Markets in Bombay.
The IOC said in a statement on Saturday that its 1996/97 (April-March) net profit rose to 14.08 billion rupees ($393.3 million), or 12.7 percent, from last years' 12.49 billion rupees.
But anaylsts predicted even better profits in 1997/98 and 1998/99.
"The year to March 1999 will be particularly strong because of the commencement of the Panipat Refinery," Dhileepan said.
IOC's 6.0 million tonne refinery at Panipat in the northern state of Haryana is slated for commissioning in 1998. It had previously been expected to start up by August 1997, a company statement said.
A 3.0 million tonne refinery in the northeastern state of Assam, is expected to be operational by 1998/99.
The company sold 41.97 million tonnes of petroleum products in 1996/97, an increase of 5.3 percent over the previous year.

The statement quoted IOC Chairman M.A. Pathan as saying: "Projects worth 100 billion rupees are under implementation and schemes of about 300 billion rupees have been identified for implementation during the ninth plan (1997-2002)."

IOC's other projects under various stages of implementation include the Haldia-Barauni crude oil pipeline, matching secondary processing facilities at Mathura, and a 3.0 million tonne expansion of the Gujarat refinery.
"A 9.0 million tonnes grassroots refinery is proposed to be set up in collaboration with Kuwait Petroleum Corporation at Paradeep on the east-cost," the statement said.
The company also plans to set up four diesel hydro-desulphurisation units at the Gujarat, Haldia, Mathura and Panipat refineries.

The company said its net interest cost had gone up to 3.10 billion rupees in 1996/97 from 1.49 billion in 1995/96 because of increased borrowings to meet a shortfall due to funds blocked with the Oil Coordination committees.
Analysts said a rise in interest costs was expected by the market and it would continue if the oil pool was not raised.

The ruling United Front coalition is set to meet on July 2 to take a decision on whether to raise prices to plug the government's mounting debt to state oil companies, estimated at 155 billion rupees ($4.3 billion) at the end of March.
Dhileepan said the Indian Oil Corporation would be a major beneficiary if the government totally deregulated the oil sector by the year 2000.

But another analyst, who did not want to be named, with a leading Franco-American investment house said the company would benefit in the short run only. "The company will benefit from deregulation in the initial few years but after 10 to 15 years things might change with some of the biggest names coming in."
Currently, a multitude of price and distribution controls place the Indian oil industry in a tightly regulated position.
The Indian government holds 91 percent of IOC's equity, employees have 5.02 percent and financial institutions and others hold the remaining stock, an official said.
IOC is India's sole importer of crude oil and refined products. It is listed among Fortune 500 companies. ($1 = 35.8 rupees)
